boardgame.name: Up Front
boardgame.description: Only once in a great while does a game dare to be truly different and abandon old concepts while striking out to chart virgin territory in game design. Rarer still are the instances in which these games succeed in presenting a simulation of unparalleled realism in an easily comprehended and playable format. In UP FRONT, we have just such a game. Gone are the hexes and charts of conventional wargames; replaced by innovative and attractive game components which have distilled a wealth of technical data into one of the most playable, yet detail laden formats ever devised._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;UP FRONT is a game of man-to-man infantry combat set in WWII Europe and is based loosely on the popular SQUAD LEADER game system. Players need not be familiar with any of the various SQUAD LEADER games or rules to play. The basic theory behind the design remains the same; only the mechanics of play differ. UP FRONT is a far simpler adaptation of SQUAD LEADER principles designed to a card game format. Yet, in many ways, the game is more realistic than its predecessor in that its inherent mechanics simulate the fear and confusion of the battlefield and the inability of leadership to assert itself far better than any tactical combat game yet published. There is no playing board; it has been replaced by Terrain cards which become the _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;ldquo;hexagons_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;rdquo; of the game as players maneuver their forces via Action cards over constantly changing terrain. The scale of the game is measured in terms of relative ranges between opposing forces, with most combat occurring within a scale distance of 500 meters during the course of player turns measured in varying seconds of actual time._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;UP FRONT is a game player_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;rsquo;s game, rich in detail yet easily playable within the space of a lunch hour. However, it also contains engrossing Multi-Player and Campaign Game versions which could last a week or more. Like SQUAD LEADER, its famous predecessor, UP FRONT is an open-ended game capable of depicting endless Design-Your-Own variations of small unit actions between American, German and Russian combatants. Tanks, Assault Guns, Smoke, Anti-Tank Rifles, Demolition Charges, Pillboxes, Partisans, SS, Entrenchments, Anti-Tank Mines, Infantry Guns, Flamethrowers, Armoured Cars, Halftracks, Panzerfausts, Bazookas, Panzerschrecks, Wire, Ambushes, Radios, Artillery, Minefields, Mortars, Snipers, Starshells, Heroes, Prisoners and Fords are all accounted for. In fact, UP FRONT encompasses almost everything that the SQUAD LEADER game system has taken four gamettes to do, and does so in a far more playable format. The game can be summed up in four words: Innovation, playability, detail and realism. That_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;rsquo;s an unbeatable combination._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;UP FRONT is rated 4 on the Avalon Hill Complexity scale of 1 (easy) to 10 (difficult)._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Recommended for two or more discriminating players of skill, ages 12 _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;amp; up._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;Each game includes: _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; 162 full-colour, quality 2_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;frac14;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;quot; _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;times; 3 _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;frac12;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;quot; playing cards_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; 120 full-colour 2_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;quot; _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;times; 2.6_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;quot; infantry cards_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; 40 full-colour 2.3_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;quot; _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;times; 3.1_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;quot; AFV cards_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; 304 double-faced .75_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;quot;, .6_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;quot;, and .5_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;quot; counters_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; 12 scenarios with up to four variations of each_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; A plastic card tray_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt; A 36-page rulebook containing Designer_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;rsquo;s Notes, Historical T, O _T_E_M_P_T_A_G_amp;amp; E charts and Campaign Game Rosters._T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_lt;br/_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_gt;

I_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ve never played this game, and so it is difficult to assess, and the instruction manual does not help much. The box is in great shape. As for the components: of the 160 playing cards, all are in good shape except two were slightly stuck together. As a result, one has a mark on the back, so you would be able to see that when it was facedown. The other one has a mark, but not over any text and it_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s not visible from the back. Another card has a very minor crease at the corner. The box says there should be 304 counters. I counted 304, but three were blank. I don_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;t know if that means that three are missing or that there were 304 counters, including the three blank ones.Otherwise, everything else looks perfect. I_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ve marked it down because of the above.

This is the complete second edition of the game. I have verified that every counter and card is present. (Well, there were a small number of unused two-color counters. Those I discarded long ago.) I am the original owner of the game, and have played it (I think) twice. In general, the game is in good condition. I’ll describe the wear, below. I’ll start with the most obvious flaw — The box has two big (about 1 1/2 inch) rips in the middle of the front. (At a guess, something too heavy was put on it at some point.) Otherwise the box is in very good condition, with a little shelf wear on one corner. (Be sure to the listed links if you would like to see the parts — especially for the parts with flaws. But beware that some of these are very big files.) http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Box/UpFrontBoxFront.JPG http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Box/UpFrontBoxRips.JPG The box bottom is in good to very good condition, with dirt and shelf wear on the corners. I’ve pictured the dirtier parts, below, as well as the whole box bottom. http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/UpFrontBacks.JPG http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Box/UpFrontBLRCorner.JPG http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Box/UpFrontBULCorner.JPG http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Box/UpFrontBURCorner.JPG I didn’t clip hanging bits of cardboard, so there is the usual (for AH games) cardboard bits on the edges. That goes (to a lesser extent) for the soldier and vehicle cards, too, since they were likewise removed from a cut sheet. As to the individual counters — The lower right corner of the Russian demolition charge has about 4mm of the surface paper raised up. A few of the morale counters have slight marring on the top or bottom edge of the counter. One “morale 0” counter has a 1/2 cm light stain. The second picture below shows the marred counters in detail. http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Counters/UpFrontAllCounters.JPG http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Counters/UpFrontMarredCounters.JPG The soldier, vehicle, and reference cards are generally clean and unmarred with good edges, but there some (about 15) with light mars. All the German soldier cards are printed about 1mm to the right, as is shown in the picture, below. (All information is visible, and there’s still a margin on the right; They’re just not exactly centered.) http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/UpFrontSoldierCards.JPG All 162 playing cards are present. There are three cards with notable mars on their backs — These are all pictured, below. (The other cards are all in very good condition, without mars.) http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Cards/UpFrontCards.JPG http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Cards/UpFrontBackBend.JPG http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Cards/UpFrontBackLineMark.JPG http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Cards/UpFrontBackRightBend.JPG http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Cards/UpFrontBackRightBend2.JPG The fronts are likewise clean and unmarred except as shown. (Make sure to look at the minefield card, which is the worst of the bunch.) http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Cards/UpFrontFrontMine5Line.JPG http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Cards/UpFrontFrontMinefield.JPG http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/Cards/UpFrontFrontRallyBend.JPG There are a few 1 cm tears to the base of the card holder. It still works fine as a card holder. (You can see the card holder in the picture above with the box bottom.) The rulebook has very slight wear on the outer edge of the pages an on its lower right corner. It is unbent and otherwise clean. http://students.washington.edu/ldubb/games/auctionPictures/Pictures/UpFrontRules.JPG Please tell me if you’re interested in purchasing this quite soon — I’m planning to take it down from BoardGameGeek a few days before Christmas for sale on eBay in January.

Artscow prints of the redesign cards (not original card art). Cards only, not counters. Original: http://boardgamegeek.com/image/211884/up-front?size=medium Redesign: http://cf.geekdo-images.com/images/pic1008224_t.jpg Another point to make, is that I decided to go with a standard back design on the cards, so all the card-backs look like this: http://cf.geekdo-images.com/images/pic1008227_t.jpg I_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ve seen some other designs that use different back images for different nations and different types of cards, but mine are all the same/standard. Full discussion on the redesign can be found here if you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;d like more info: http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/458796/up-front-redesign/pag... For some reason I have extra cards. For example, in the original up front there were, apparently, 41 American cards, but I have 44. All are clearly numbered from 1-44, so I suspect the extra 3 may be from expansions (I know the Banzai expansion included several extra American_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;s, so this may be it). But there are also extra Russians and Germans, so I suspect the extras may have come from promos over the years that were included in the redesign. As a result, I have 7 decks of 54 cards. This includes the complete Action deck, the Personality cards, plus some extra blanks that I printed off [just in case I later lost or damage a card]. They are in excellent condition, and have pretty much remained in their cases (plastic artscow containers) unplayed. The quality of the printing is also excellent, and I_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;d be happy to take some photos if you_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;d like to check. There should be A (1-5), A (6-10, B(1-5), B (6-10). But instead of this I_T_E_M_P_T_A_G_#039;ve printed 2x A (1-5), 2x B (1-5), etc.
